explanation:
To determine whether send_iov_nontls participates in direct or indirect recursion you must examine all functions it calls and all functions that can call it (and their callees), because recursion can occur through any cycle in that call graph. Explanations per symbol:

- pre_send_setopt: Called directly by send_iov_nontls; its body must be checked to ensure it does not (directly or indirectly) call send_iov_nontls, creating a cycle.
- post_send_setopt: Called directly by send_iov_nontls; its body (and any calls it makes) must be inspected for paths back to send_iov_nontls.
- MHD_DLOG: Called by post_send_setopt (per static graph). Include to ensure logging does not call back into connection/send paths that could reach send_iov_nontls.
- MHD_send_iovec_: Listed caller of send_iov_nontls; its implementation must be checked for any call chains that could lead back into send_iov_nontls (indirect recursion).
- MHD_connection_handle_write: Caller of MHD_send_iovec_; include because a cycle could involve higher-level callers calling down and then back up into send_iov_nontls.
- MHD_send_data_: Appears in the static graph as a caller of pre_send_setopt/post_send_setopt; include to verify whether it (or functions it calls) can create a cycle involving send_iov_nontls.
- MHD_send_hdr_and_body_: Same reason as MHD_send_data_ — it calls pre/post_send_setopt and may be part of an indirect recursion path.
- MHD_send_sendfile_: Same reason — calls pre/post_send_setopt; its body must be checked for paths back to send_iov_nontls.

Providing these function definitions/bodies (or a reliable call graph that includes their transitive callees) lets the next analyzer determine whether any call path forms a cycle that violates the MISRA rule prohibiting direct or indirect self-calls.
